In the background are the station ownerFazle Karim Fazl, with former U.S. AmbassadorKarl EikenberryandMinistry of Communications (Afghanistan)Afghan Communications MinisterAmirzai SanginSangin Amirzai.Communications in Afghanistanis under the control of theMinistry of Communications and Information Technology (Afghanistan)Ministry of Communications and Information Technology(MCIT). It has rapidly expanded after thePresidency of Hamid KarzaiKarzai administrationtook over in late 2001, and has embarked on wireless companies, internet, radio stations and television channels. The Afghan government signed a $64.5 agreement in 2006 with China'sZTEon the establishment of a countrywideoptical fibercable network. The project began to improve telephone, internet, television and radio broadcast services throughoutAfghanistan. As of 2014, about 90% of thedemography of Afghanistancountry's populationhas access to communication services.cite newshttp://www.pajhwok.com/en/2014/01/01/90pc-afghans-get-access-telecom-services90pc of Afghans get access to telecom services[[Pajhwok Afghan News]]Muhammad HassanKhetabJanuary 1, 20142014-07-10

There are about 18 millionmobile phoneusers in the country.Etisalat,Roshan (Telecom)Roshan,Afghan WirelessandMTN GroupMTNare the leading telecom companies. Etisalat became the first company planning to launch4Gservices in 2014.cite newshttp://www.pajhwok.com/en/2013/02/20/etisalat-set-launch-4g-internet-serviceEtisalat set to launch 4G Internet servicePajhwok Afghan NewsFebruary 20, 201324 March 2013It is predicted that over 50% of the population will have access to the internet by 2015.cite newshttp://www.pajhwok.com/en/2012/09/22/govt-issues-third-3g-licence-roshanGovt issues third 3G licence to RoshanPajhwok Afghan NewsWedaBarakiSeptember 22, 20122014-07-10In 2014, Afghanistan leased a spacesatellitefromEutelsat, calledEutelsat 48DAFGHANSAT 1.
article.heading: Telephone
article.paragraph: FurtherTelephone numbers in AfghanistanThere are about 18 millionGSMmobile phonesubscribers in Afghanistan as of 2009, with over 75,000 fixed-telephone-lines and little over 190,000code division multiple accessCDMAsubscribers.cite webhttp://mcit.gov.af/enStatistics[[Ministry of Communications (Afghanistan)]]2006January 17, 2012Whitepages.af, phone system in AfghanistanMobile communications have improved because of the introduction of wireless carriers into thisdeveloping country. The first wasAfghan Wireless, which is US based that was founded byEhsan Bayat. The second wasRoshan (telco)Roshan, which began providing services to all major cities within Afghanistan. There are also a number ofVSATstations in major cities such asKabul,Kandahar,Herat,Mazari Sharif, andJalalabad, providing international and domestic voice/data connectivity. article.paragraph: All the companies providing communication services are obligated to deliver 2.5% of their income to the communication development fund annually. According to the Ministry of Communication and Information Technology there are 4760 active towers throughout the country which covers 85% of the population. The Ministry of Communication and Information Technology plans to expand its services in remote parts of the country where the remaining 15% of the population will be covered with the installation of 700 new towers.
Phone calls in Afghanistan have been monitored by theNational Security Agencyaccording toWikileaks.

article.heading: Television
article.paragraph: mainTelevision in AfghanistanThere are over 50 Afghan television channels worldwide, many of which are based inside Afghanistan while others are broadcast from North America and Europe. Selected foreign channels are also shown to the public in Afghanistan, but with the use of the internet, over 3,500 international TV channels may be accessed in Afghanistan.Satellite Direct

article.paragraph: MainRadio stations in AfghanistanAs of 2007, there are an estimated 50 privateradiostations throughout the country. Broadcasts are inDari PersianDari,Pashto languagePashto,English languageEnglish,Uzbek languageUzbekiand many other languages.

The number of radio listeners are decreasing and are being slowly outnumbered bytelevision. Of Afghanistan's 6 main cities,KandaharandKhosthave a lot of radio listeners.KabulandJalalabadhave moderate number of listeners. article.heading: Postal service
article.paragraph: See alsoAfghan PostPostage stamps and postal history of AfghanistanIn 1870, a centralpost officewas established atBala Hissar, KabulBala Hissarin Kabul and a post office in the capital of each province. The service was slowly being expanded over the years as more postal offices were established in each large city by 1918. Afghanistan became a member of theUniversal Postal Unionin 1928,Cite newshttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-14806350Kabul: Streets with no names2011-09-30BBC NewsSeptember 29, 2011and the postal administration elevated to theAfghan Ministry of CommunicationsMinistry of Communicationin 1934.cite webhttp://afghanpost.gov.af/about.htmafghanpost.gov.af - AboutCivil war caused a disruption in issuing official stamps during the 1980s-90s warcite webhttp://digilander.libero.it/fabioalarici/a.htmlPostal Authorities Abut in 1999 postal service was operating again. Postal services to/from Kabul worked remarkably well all throughout the war years. Postal services to/from Herat resumed in 1997.cite webhttp://www.afghan-network.net/Culture/stamps.htmlAfghanistan @ StampsThe Afghan government has reported to the UPU several times about illegal stamps being issued and sold in 2003 and 2007.cite webhttp://www.upu.int/philately/en/2003/002_upu_circular_en.pdf2003 UPU Circularcite webhttp://www.upu.int/philately/en/2007/177_upu_circular_en.pdf2007 UPU Circular

Afghanistan Post has been reorganizing the postal service in 2000s with the help ofPakistan Post.The Afghanistan Postal commission was formed to prepare a written policy for the development of the postal sector, which will form the basis of a new postal services law governing licensing of postal services providers. The project was expected to finish by 2008.cite webhttp://www.mcit.gov.af/Documents/RunningProjects/AfghanPost.pdfAfghanistan Postal commission
article.heading: Satellite
article.paragraph: MainEutelsat 48DIt was announced in 2013 that Afghanistan would soon have its ownsatellitein space.cite webhttp://www.pajhwok.com/en/2013/02/17/3-firms-ready-launch-afghan-satellite3 firms ready to launch Afghan satellitePajhwok Afghan NewsMuhammad HassanKhetabFebruary 17, 20132014-07-10In January 2014 the Afghan Ministry of Communications and Information Technology signed an agreement withEutelsatfor the use of satellite resources to enhance deployment of Afghanistan's national broadcasting and telecommunications infrastructure as well as its international connectivity. AFGHANSAT 1 was officially launched in May 2014, with expected service for at least seven years in Afghanistan. The Afghan government plans to launch AFGHANSAT 2 after the AFGHANSAT 1 lease ends.cite newsAfghanistan's maiden satellite launchedhttp://www.pajhwok.com/en/2014/05/10/afghanistan%E2%80%99s-maiden-satellite-launchedPajhwok Afghan NewsMuhammad HassanKhetab10 May 20142014-05-10
